He squealed, curled up, and sat awkwardly while in immense pain. I noticed that he was swelling and turned red on his hand, up his forearm, and across his shoulder just a few minutes after being stung. With his profile, he seemed to be a candidate for anaphylaxis, so I drove him to the closest urgent care clinic (which was surprisingly unhelpful) and on to the closest ER. They confirmed I was right on the diagnosis and swiftly treated him with a dose of epinephrine, and he was fine after that. He was super grateful to have a friend who knew enough about health so he did not end up in a scary situation.

Text_Numeracy: As a pharmacist, I have plenty of experiences that demonstrate my knowledge of health or medical issues.  A few years ago, I had a mother come to my pharmacy who mention her 6 year old son, who had been diagnosed with ADHD.  He was taking Adderall 5 mg once daily and Ritalin 5 mg as needed for school.  The mother noticed that her son was having a hard time concentrating in school so   she increase his Ritalin as needed dosage from 5 mg  to 10 mg and she also increase the Adderall from 5 mg to 10 mg.  I explained to her the dangers of increasing these doses without consulting the physician about these dosage increases.  I also spoke to her about the dangers of overdosing on these medications.  This experience demonstrated my knowledge of health and medical issues because I was able to keep this child safe from these medications.

I had to learn medical terms and know when to ask for clarifications. Ultimately, I had to organize a bunch of information about how to care for the family member in an effective way.
Text_Anxiety: no reply
Text_TrustPhys: I think every person has their own motivations for what they do no matter what job they have. Doctors are human like everybody else and tend to do what benefits them the most. Are they willing to push pills and surgery to line their pockets or are they willing to look out for my best interests.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I think I have a pretty good capacity. I can always ask questions or read literature if I feel uncertain about anything. I generally make good decisions regarding my health.

Text_Numeracy: Nursing school had given me plenty of knowledge in this area as well as some personal experience. I was able to identify and intervene when a friend experienced a seizure at a bar.
Text_Anxiety: Generally when i go to the doctors office my biggest concern is what is going to be the result of the visit. Am I going to get bad news that I was not expecting or just something that is easily taken care of.
Text_TrustPhys: I think it's a big part of their job to build/earn your trust as a patient.  I think if it's not given or wanted there are other more professional or moral decisions to be made by both parties.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I feel that recent information that has been given to me about my health is not thourough or inclusive enough to completely understand what is needing to be done for myself. I'm sometimes left with having to google additional information or ask more invasive questions than necessary because of the vague information that is presented to me.

Text_Numeracy: My knowledge of health and medical issues comes from clinical experience, both in medical school and as a resident physician. For example, as I was training in psychiatry, I diagnosed someone with obsessive compulsive disorder. I was able to do this through a careful clinical history and characterization of the patients experience and symptoms.
Text_Anxiety: Yes, I feel anxious when I meet doctors. I worry that they may tell me something is wrong or I may have some serious illness.
Text_TrustPhys: “How about us”Rife makes "you" perfectly & praise you quietly. Mysteriously you you always arrive at the right time! thankyou . In the room alone "with you" it feels like a wall disappears I can breathe. I am so grateful for “YOU” & your input ! ! Rife,  Rife, Rife" Was this helpful?
Text_SubjectiveLit: I feel like I have a decent capacity to do this.  It's never been a problem for me in the past, though I feel like doing health information online is sometimes a bit sketchy.

Text_Numeracy: I recall a time when I was experiencing some unusual symptoms, and rather than relying solely on a primary care physician, I took the initiative to research my condition extensively. I learned about the interaction of the various prescription drugs I was taking and how they might contribute to my symptoms. This knowledge enabled me to have a more informed discussion with the psychologist I was visiting, leading to adjustments in my medication. I find that my proactive approach to health not only helps me maintain my well-being but also deepens my understanding of medical issues.
Text_Anxiety: I don't really feel anxiety when I meet doctors; I see it more as a routine part of my active lifestyle. Since I'm used to visiting them regularly, it's just another appointment on my calendar. I guess if anything makes me slightly uneasy, it might be the idea of discussing my medication or any potential changes, but I have confidence in my self-control and generally feel positive about my well-being. Ultimately, the focus is on maintaining my physical activity and ensuring I stay healthy.
Text_TrustPhys: I actually don't have a primary care physician, and my experiences with doctors have been mixed. On one hand, I trust them to provide me with the necessary prescriptions and advice for my medication needs, especially since I’m very proactive about my health and engage in rigorous physical activities. However, I often feel that the focus can be more on treating symptoms rather than the holistic approach I’m looking for. I appreciate doctors who are open to discussing all aspects of my well-being and can communicate effectively, but sometimes it feels like there’s a lack of that connection in the medical community.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I feel confident in my ability to obtain, process, and understand basic health information and services needed to make appropriate health decisions. I am highly organized and dependable, which helps me keep track of my prescription medications and health-related information. Additionally, my active lifestyle and enthusiasm for trying new activities mean that I stay informed about health and wellness trends. While I may not have a primary care physician, I seek out information and resources actively, ensuring I access the necessary services to maintain my health.
